posts.name: Marcel
posts.cooked:
It would be nice to be notified about new stories from selected people or groups. When a story from such a user/group is received a notification is created with a message like ‚ÄúA new story from XY is available‚Äù.

This prevents having to check regularly to keep up to date of important contacts. It also makes Signal a better alternative to, i.e., Snapchat.

Story notifications should be strictly opt-in and configurable for each user/group. The default user experience stays unchanged.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: The whole point of Stories is to share passively. If you want to generate a notification then you can send a standard message.

posts.name: Marcel
posts.cooked: But then I decide that the others get notifications. That is not what I am proposing, quite the opposite actually. I am proposing that the receiver can decide if they want notifications.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: They can already decide if/what notifications they receive when with standard messages. I‚Äôm not really seeing what value this would add.

posts.name: Marcel
posts.cooked:
If you only look at the notifications, yes standard messages work almost exactly the same.

But for me this comes down to the purpose of each medium. Messages (for me) are for conversations - bidirectional and all sides are participating. I use them to ask questions or write to others with the expectation that I get a response (as soon as possible). My messages are mostly text and people should not mute my conversation.

Stories on the other hand are (or I want them to be) more like social media. They are a way to update the people around me on what I am doing. I can send as many pictures without disturbing my contacts with many notifications. Stories are also mostly a unidirectional broadcast where I do not care when/if the others see them. I do however want to closely follow, i.e., my close family which would be greatly helped by notifications.

So for me these are two separate mediums which deserve/require two different notification settings. They have a different user interface for a reason. There is also the difference that for messages notifications are enabled by default, for stories they should be disabled by default.

I just think Signal could serve a Snapchat-like use-case with minimal changes to the clients only.

posts.name: BBou
posts.cooked:
I like the idea! Instead of ‚Äújust give me notifications for stories‚Äù, being able to control which people you get notifications from if they share a story is a good option to have.

Definitely wouldn‚Äôt mind getting notifications from my family and close friends when they share stories. I‚Äôll the stories of the the rest of my contacts when I decide to open the stories tab.

Good idea

Avitus:

I‚Äôm not really seeing what value this would add.

Stories by design don‚Äôt generate notifications so you can spam them to your heart‚Äôs content without bothering anyone, but I guess some people want to be notified anyway, so adding the option would allow them to choose to receive notifications for stories without it requiring that the sender change how they are choosing to share things.

I basically just use Signal with family, I‚Äôve setup a family group and have a family stories section. The problem is that we are not actively chatting every day, sometimes we can go a week without chatting. So the only way we can share videos and photos that we know each other will see is in the group. This means it eats up everyone‚Äôs storage space on their phones and is part of the chat history. Stories are virtually useless to us because we don‚Äôt check Signal every day, nor do we want that to be a habit or something we have to think about.

That being said, stories would be the absolute perfect medium for us if we could get notifications. It solves our group message spam and keeps more free space on our devices. Basically for us, without notifications, stories are un-usable. However, if we could get notifications (even if it were limited notifications ‚Äúyou have X new stories‚Äù), they would be so incredibly useful. If notifications are too much, letting me set a default expire time (like 2 weeks or 1 month) may also solve my problem. Also, we don‚Äôt want expiring messages in our group chat, so that‚Äôs not an option.

PhotonFalcon:

we don‚Äôt want expiring messages in our group chat, so that‚Äôs not an option.

Why not? If you are wanting to share something that everyone is guaranteed to see, but also avoid filling storage and keeping them in the chat history, disappearing messages are the perfect option for that ‚Äì just toggle it on to send the message, then turn it back off. You could also create a separate ‚ÄúStories‚Äù group chat that has disappearing messages enabled so you don‚Äôt have to deal with toggling it and having those kinds of things mixed with your regular chat. That has the benefit of already supporting notifications as well.

True, we could setup a separate group (something I‚Äôve done with subsets of family members). However it lacks what we‚Äôre interested in for the Stories. We like the feature, it just isn‚Äôt useful in the way that works for people who don‚Äôt open the app every day. In fact multiple (duplicate) groups degrades our experience.

My family took some work to get onto Signal, we go across a few generations, for the most part they understand ‚Äústories‚Äù (from other apps) but having them in multiple (basically duplicate groups) would be confusing and people would post messages they wanted to keep in the wrong group. We already have some of that happen fairly often hah.

It basically makes more of a mess. Stories are nice because they separate clutter and are a completely different flow and divides up things so they are not confusing. It‚Äôs a nice feature, just sad we can‚Äôt really use it effectively.

Currently it seems like a copy/paste from social media, but those make sense because they use addictions to drive people into the app, causing them to watch stories. In Signal, we don‚Äôt have that addiction (thankfully!) and so it seems like it just is a little out of place without some timing controls/notifications.

The Story feature works well. I love how I can have a story dedicated to my group chat. My only issue is that I‚Äôm not receiving notifications for replies within specific stories. It makes it hard to have continued engagement on a particular subject. I understand that having notifications for every story post would be annoying, but it‚Äôs not so bad if it‚Äôs replies that you‚Äôre involved in, like your own post or comments you made in other posts.

For me, it‚Äôs generally the case that I create a story and then these stories are seen exactly 0 times. Many then do not look 24h in Signal purely and do not see the stories. Who communicates exclusively via Signal may look several times a day in Signal. But that is not the rule. After almost 10 stories in the last months, maybe 6 people have registered about 3 stories at all. That is a pity. A message that a new story is available would be really helpful.

I use Signal often - but if I do not write messages by my own but only react on messages I receive from others (going directly to it by notification) I do not open the main window and do not see the stories tab.
It would be good to get some kind of notification that stories arrived. If not as normal Android/iOS notifications (by default disabled for those who do not need it) then at least as some hint on the back arrow on top left side of chat window.

For me one of the purposes of posting a Story instead of a pic is to reduce digital waste. I.e. if I would like to send my wife a pic about a dish that turned out great or something funny my cat just did, it will be deleted 24h later. Otherwise it will be stored in our devices indefinitely.
So the notification option would be amazing. Right now I have to send the recipient an additional message saying ‚Äúcheck the stories‚Äù, which is quite annoying.
Also the option of turning on expiring messages will not work for me, because I don‚Äôt want all my messages to be deleted.

Rastic:

turning on expiring messages will not work for me, because I don‚Äôt want all my messages to be deleted.

You can turn it on for the one message, then back off. You can also send as a view once image.

What?

Have Signal check periodically every few hours for any Stories not yet viewed by the user.

If there is at least one, show a notification to the user that there are unread Stories. This way, notification spam is avoided when a large number of Stories are received at once.

This notification can be turned off, whether by turning it off directly or by completely disabling Stories altogether.

Why?

Direct messages and Group messages create notifications for the user to get their attention. In contrast, currently Stories do not create any notification at all.

This is understandable to a point. Stories are not ‚Äúdirect communication‚Äù, they should not burden the receiver with the expectation of an immediate view or response.

The problem is that a lot of the users I‚Äôve talked to frequently do not open the app and check for unviewed Stories. This is compounded by the fact that Stories have a lifetime for 24 hours, so there is a limited window to view any specific Story.

It is extremely poor user experience to expect a user to open an app every few hours just to see if they have received any communication, whether it‚Äôs a message or a Story. Even more so for communication with an in-built time limit.

This does not go against any public ‚ÄúStory standard‚Äù. For example, Instagram sends periodic notifications if there are unread stories. Adding this optional functionality does not turn Signal into a ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù app as the user is always in control.

How?

  • Add a toggle to the Story settings to enable notifications for unread stories. Default this setting to on.
    • The receiver may not know about Stories the first time they receive a Story, so they won‚Äôt know how to get into the Settings to turn it on themselves!
    • Add some friendly UI to show the user how to get to the Story settings, so they can turn off the notification or disable Stories altogether. Maybe update the ‚ÄúStory tour‚Äù the user receives on a fresh install?
  • If the setting is on, every hour/few hours (customizable?) the Signal app checks for any unviewed stories. If there‚Äôs at least one, show a notification in the user‚Äôs notification tray.
    • This is to limit ‚Äúnotification spam‚Äù if a user sends multiple Stories or a bunch of users each send a Story!
  • (Optional / Later) Further control over what the notification says, just like how you can control how incoming message notifications look. ‚ÄúYou have unviewed Stories.‚Äù, ‚ÄúYou have unviewed Stories from # contacts.‚Äù, ‚ÄúYou have unviewed Stories from Bob, Nancy, and 3 others.‚Äù, etc.
  • (Optional / Later) Allow the user to specify contacts they do/don‚Äôt want to receive Story notifications for.
    • Example: I keep in touch with my family members on Signal. Some of them post political memes I don‚Äôt agree with as Stories. I shouldn‚Äôt get notified for Stories from them, but I still want to receive notifications for Stories from other users. And I don‚Äôt remove those family members because I have to talk to them from time to time.

Current Alternatives

  • Send a Direct message to each receiver of your story ‚ÄúI sent you a new story‚Äù so they receive a notification.
    • Forcing the Story sender to do extra work, adding the expectation of an immediate read, have to do it every time you send a new Story.
  • Create a Group chat for each ‚Äútype‚Äù of Story (dog pictures, video game memes, workout pictures, etc.) and send Group messages so they receive a notification.
    • On top of the expectation of an immediate read, each ‚ÄúStory Group‚Äù needs to manage the users in the group, and users in that group have to reveal they are in that group to other users.
  • Not engage with the Story system at all, because most or all of the recipients of your Stories will never see them, even if they wanted to.
    • This has been my experience and I bet a lot of others as well. I send Stories frequently in other apps, I just wish Signal‚Äôs implementation wasn‚Äôt so unreliable.

posts.name: George Clinton
posts.cooked: All I want is the ability to turn on a notification badge when there‚Äôs a new story. I avoid the addictive part of mobile devices by only interacting with them when I have a specific requirement or when I receive a notification. Requiring me to check signal to look for a new story would be the exact addictive behavior that I don‚Äôt want.

posts.name: Turkeysanwich
posts.cooked: The ideal implementation of this for me personally would be a once-a-day notification if there are any new stories to view, or a granular toggle for each contact/group story. Having no option for notifications almost completely negates the usefulness of stories when you or your contacts don‚Äôt open Signal on a daily basis.

WhatsApp is currently working on a feature for status/story notifications from select contacts:

WABetaInfo ‚Äì 1 Aug 25

WhatsApp beta for Android 2.25.22.10: what's new? | WABetaInfo

The WhatsApp beta for Android 2.25.22.10 update from Google Play uncovers a new feature to receive notifications for status updates.
